column2: Code of Practice for Ear Piercing Operations

column4: A Code of Practice for Ear-Piercing Operations

column1: This guidance has been produced to aid practitioners in understanding their legal responsibilities relating to ear piercing. It also gives advice on what is considered best practice with regard to piercing operations.

It is a legal requirement that all persons carrying out ear-piercing activities within the Borough must have a Certificate of Registration from Tameside MBC, for themselves and for their business premises.

Applications for a license can be obtained online and must be completed and posted back to the Licensing Office, Ash Road, Droylsden, M43 6QU. Click here to register the Premises 123.23 KB, or here to register an Operative 119.72 KB
The Local Authority has adopted the following bye-laws under the provisions of s.14(7) Local Government (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1982, which apply to all ear-piercers within the Borough:
1. For the purpose of securing the cleanliness of premises and fittings therein a proprietor shall ensure that -

• All internal walls, doors, windows, partitions, floors and floor coverings and ceilings in any part of the premises used by clients and operators are kept clean and in such good repair as to enable them to be cleaned effectively;

• All waste material and other litter, arising from the treatment, is placed in suitable covered receptacles, which are washable and leakproof, or use a leakproof liner bag. The receptacles shall be emptied, or the bags changed, at least once every working day, or more frequently as necessary and the material disposed of safely. Where liners are not used, the receptacles shall then be cleaned;

• All needles used in treatment are placed after use in separate covered and leakproof re-usable boxes, or disposable 'sharps' containers designed for the purpose. When re-usable needles are used they shall be placed in a designated container marked "dirty" and emptied at least once every working day or more frequently as necessary. The contents must then be sterilised for re-use and placed in a clearly marked "sterile" container. Where sharps containers are used they shall be disposed of safely as clinical waste
• All furniture and fittings in the treatment area are kept clean and in such good repair as to enable them to be cleaned effectively;

• All tables, couches and seats used by clients in the treatment area and any surface on which the items specified in 2b below are placed immediately prior to treatment have a smooth impervious surface which is wiped down regularly with detergent and water. Any blood stained areas should be cleaned using a 1 in 10 solution of Household Bleach, or a 500-1000ppm Hypochlorite Solution;
• Where tables or couches are used, they shall be covered by a disposable paper sheet which shall be changed for each client;
• A notice or notices reading "No Smoking" are prominently displayed within the treatment area.
2. For the purpose of securing the cleansing and, so far as is appropriate, the sterilisation of instruments, materials and equipment used in connection with the treatment -

• An operator shall ensure that, before use in connection with treatment, any gown, wrap or other protective clothing, paper or other covering, towel, cloth or other such articles use in the treatment -
• is clean and in good repair, and, so far as is appropriate, is sterile;
• has not previously been used in connection with any other client unless it consists of a material which can be and has been adequately cleaned and, so far as is appropriate, sterilised;

• An operator shall ensure that any needle, metal instrument, or other item of equipment used in treatment or for handling instruments and needles used in treatment, is in a sterile condition and kept sterile until it is used. Items should be re-sterilised if they are not used within 3 hours of the previous sterilisation.

• adequate facilities and equipment for the purpose of sterilisation (unless pre-sterilised items are used) and of cleansing, as required in pursuance of these bye-laws. An autoclave is the only adequate method of sterilisation;
• sufficient and safe gas points and/or electrical socket outlets to enable compliance with these bye-laws;
• an adequate constant supply of clean hot and cold water readily available at all times on the premises;

• adequate storage for all items mentioned in bye-law 2 a and b above, so that those items shall be properly stored in a clean and suitable place so as to avoid, as far as possible, the risk of contamination.
3. For the purpose of securing the cleanliness of operators -
• An operator whilst giving treatment shall ensure that -
• he keeps any open boil, sore, cut or open wound on an exposed part of his body effectively covered by an impermeable dressing;
• he does not smoke or consume food or drink;
• suitable and sufficient washing facilities for the use of operators, including hot and cold water and a sanitising soap or detergent;
• suitable and sufficient sanitary accommodation for operators.
There are 2 methods of ear-piercing that are recommended, largely because they eliminate the need for personal handling of contact articles and equipment by the operative.
Any method that requires the on-site sterilization of needles, studs or sleepers should be avoided.

• Coren Method - This involves the use of a U-shaped plastic holder containing a stud at one end and a butterfly at the other, in a pre-sterilised bubble pack. The holder cannot be re-used and must be disposed of. This method presents little or no risk of contamination of the stud or holder.

• Inverness Method and Derivatives - This involves the use of a gun, into which are loaded pre-sterilised studs and butterflies. There is no personal contact with the stud prior to discharge and therefore there is no real risk of contamination in normal use. Where double packs of studs are used, if only one ear is pierced then the remaining stud must be disposed of.

It is advisable to keep written records of the name and address of every client and the date of the ear-piercing. Accurate records can be valuable if there is any question of an infection problem at a later date and can often help to protect the practitioner, for example, if the incubation period is too long or too short for infection to have been transmitted to the customer by the practitioner. Records should be retained for a minimum of one year.
The following model procedure should be adopted when piercing ears:
• Wash and dry hands at beginning of session.
• Seat customer, mark ear lobes, preferably with gentian violet pen.
• Place clean paper tissue or towel on table top, or customer's shoulder.
• Clean customer's ears with spirit swab (eg. medi-swab).
• Wash operator's hands again and dry with a paper towel.
• Open pre-sterilised pack and pierce ears.
• Adjust tightness of earring in each ear using clean tissue to hold earring.
• Dispose of plastic capsules or holders, swabs, and paper tissues and towel in plastic-lined bin.
• Wash hands again and dry with a paper towel.
• Begin again at (2) on next customer. If the earrings required adjustment after inserting into the ear lobe, begin at (1).
Suitable and sufficient information on after-care should be given to the client. It is recommended that written information is provided.
• No antibiotic lotions, creams or ointments should be used on the pierced ear, unless prescribed by a doctor.

• Keeping the ear clean and dry should be adequate protection. If the ear becomes wet after washing or bathing, it should be dried with a clean paper tissue. The use of antiseptics should be avoided, as they can cause allergies. Surgical spirit may be used sparingly, if absolutely necessary.
